title: DigiYatra Campaign: When data privacy concerns halt growth, Marketing & Advertising News, ET BrandEquity
text: [Marketing](/news/marketing)- 4 min read When data privacy concerns halt growth Data privacy and protection have become standard concerns in an increasingly digitalized world. Brands are increasingly communicating their data privacy and protection features to consumers to build trust. DigiYatra’s recent campaign, ‘Don’t Know Your Customer,’ highlights why such initiatives must communicate simply and effectively to influence people’s behaviour. There’s no doubt that Indian consumers value data privacy and protection. A PwC Voice of the Consumer Survey 2024 highlighted that 82% of Indian consumers consider the protection of personal data as the most crucial factor in building trust. This can lead to consumer behaviours such as enabling location-based services on a device, discontinuing the use of an app, or deleting a social media account. Few consumers trust companies to protect their personal data and are increasingly taking matters into their own hands to safeguard their privacy. Brands are realising that being data compliant and adhering to prevailing laws is not enough—they must also clearly communicate their efforts to protect users' data and security. Case in point: the massive campaigns by WhatsApp,[Google](/tag/google), and Truecaller to communicate their privacy features to users. Launched in 2022, DigiYatra has been rolled out across 24 airports in the country, with plans to expand to 4-5 more airports in the coming months. The app has 6.3 million users, who have collectively used it over 33 million times across Indian airports. This remarkable growth has been driven solely by on-ground marketing at partner airports and through social media. DigiYatra uses facial recognition technology to verify a passenger’s identity, reducing airport entry time from an average of 15-20 seconds to 3-5 seconds. Multiplied by lakhs of daily airline passengers (4.84 lakh on a single record day), this results in significant time savings and operational efficiencies at airports. DigiYatra aims to further reduce these times by implementing an open gate entry system. Despite its success, DigiYatra has faced concerns from users via emails and social media, suggesting that it stores personal data and may use it for surveillance. We take a different approach by saying, ‘We don’t want to know you,’ thereby mitigating the risk of data loss, theft, leakage, or misuse. DigiYatra uses a self-sovereign identity based on verifiable credentials (Aadhaar) and decentralised identifiers, built on the trust layer of Hyperledger Aries.” As a technology leader, Khadakbhavi frequently speaks at industry events to share DigiYatra’s success story. At one such event, he recounted, “I showcased our self-sovereign identity system and explained how we don’t store passenger PII. Afterward, a delegate approached me, thanked me for the clarification, and said, ‘I hadn’t installed DigiYatra because I thought you were storing my data for surveillance. Now that I understand, I’ll install the app.’” This encounter was a pivotal moment for Khadakbhavi and his team. By polling industry event audiences, he found that while 70-80% had installed DigiYatra, few knew the app did not collect PII. Know Your Customer (KYC) guidelines, originally designed for the BFSI industry, have since permeated other sectors. KYC aims to prevent financial fraud, money laundering, and terrorist financing. However, as KYC compliance becomes more widespread, consumers may find the information requests intrusive and burdensome, potentially deterring them from engaging with businesses. Concerns also exist around how collected data may be used. On the flip side, KYC has enabled businesses to offer personalised digital services and enhance customer experiences. Khadakbhavi remarked, “Now that DigiYatra has a solid user base and high adoption rates, we aim to strengthen the platform’s credibility. The d-KYC campaign is designed to transparently communicate our unique and innovative approach to managing passenger PII—we don’t store your data and don’t know you.” The future of global aviation is poised to be far more interconnected and seamless, with initiatives like DigiYatra being piloted worldwide. That’s the value proposition of DigiYatra and One ID.” He continued, “Traditional frequent flyer or trusted traveller programs are restricted to domestic airports. But with DigiYatra and One ID, a passenger’s identity will be consistent across departure and destination airports.” Similarly, the European Digital Identity (EUDI) initiative aims to create a universal, secure digital identity and wallet. By integrating EUDI with DigiYatra’s decentralised system, India and EU citizens can enjoy seamless air travel between the two regions. According to Khadakbhavi, this represents a major step forward for global citizens.
